work.p: This manuscript features drafts of lines and ideas that appeared, in a revised form, in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Song of Myself." The drafted lines relate to the portion of the poem that ultimately became sections 48 and 49.

titleStmt.title: There is no word in
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. It includes drafts of lines and ideas that appeared in a revised form in the first poem in that edition, titled "Leaves of Grass," eventually titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript has been mounted, so no image of the verso is available.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: There is no word in any tongue
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: edited editorial note, updated transcription, added inline relations info

lg.l: There is no word in any tongue,
No array, no form of symbol,

Who would prove define
the scope and purpose
of God.—

Mostly this we have of God: we have
Man.—

Which of a night shines in some turbid
pool,

And there are sparkles mad and
tossed and broken,
And their archetype is the Sun.

I can comprehend no being more wonderful
than Man;
